spec.description:
Overview of metrics from Prometheus 2.0.  
Useful for using prometheus to monitor your prometheus.

panels.description:

panels.title: Created Chunks

panels.description:
Total number of time series in prometheus

The amount of the current series of the heard block in Prometheus, real-time data, the head block is on the running memory, and the data can be modified

A time series is considered active if Prometheus scraped new data for it recently. Prometheus provides prometheus_tsdb_head_series metric, which shows the number of active time series. Prometheus holds recently added samples for active time series in RAM, so its RAM usage highly depends on the number of active time series. The number of active time series is connected to cardinality via churn rate. See this article on how to estimate RAM usage for Prometheus from the number of active time series and ingestion rate
for link (https://www.robustperception.io/how-much-ram-does-prometheus-2-x-need-for-cardinality-and-ingestion)

panels.description: Total number of appended samples at prometheus start to now
panels.title: Total samples

panels.description:
Total number of appended samples

Prometheus can achieve 1.3 bytes per sample compression in production, but prefers to use 2 bytes per sample to be conservative when estimating. Prometheus has a default retention period of 15 days, so 100,000 samples per second over 15 days is about 240 GB. The next question is how much RAM you need. Storage work in Prometheus 2.x is in chunks that are written out every two hours and then compressed into larger time frames. The storage engine does not cache internally, but uses the kernel's page cache. So you need enough RAM to hold the blocks, plus overhead, and RAM used during queries. 12 hours of sample ingestion is a good starting point, so 100,000 samples per second is about 8 GB

panels.description:
This is an estimate of churn, with series being added to the cache being considered churn. This will have both false positives (e.g. series appearing and disappearing) and false negatives (e.g. series hit sample_limit, but still created in head block), but should be generally useful as-is

An estimate of the churn rate. Series loads into the cache are considered churn rates. But there are chances of false positives (e.g. series that flashes and disappears) and false negatives (e.g. Series hits sample_limit but is still created in the head block), but generally use as-is
panels.title: Series churn

panels.description: Samples in to remote storage, compare to samples out for queue managers
panels.title: send samples
